```python
# To create 1D array (5,) aka list
array = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

# To create 2D array (5,1)
array = [[9],[9],[9],[9],[9]]

# To create 2D array (1,5)
array = [[9, 9, 9, 9, 9]]
```
```{python}
import numpy as np
array_2d = np.array([[9, 9, 9, 9, 9]])
array_1d = np.array([1,1,1,1,1])
print(array_2d + array_1d)
print((array_2d+array_1d).shape)
```

- 2D-array of (1,5) $+$ 1D-array aka list of (5,):
    - 2D-array of (1,5)

```{python}
import numpy as np
array_2d = np.array([[1], [2], [3], [4], [5]])

# Create a 1D array of shape (5,)
array_1d = np.array([10, 20, 30, 40, 50])

# Add the 2D array and 1D array
result = array_2d + array_1d

print(result)
print(result.shape)

```

- 2D-array of (5,1) $+$ 1D-array aka list of (5,):
    - 2D-array of (5,5) this is due to [broadcasting](https://jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook/02.05-computation-on-arrays-broadcasting.html) see fig below
